name: 1,3,5-Hexatriene

energies.comment: CRITICAL CONTROL: Same 6 π-electrons as benzene but LINEAR (not cyclic). Shows +74 kJ/mol conjugation stabilization from π-delocalization across chain, LESS than benzene's +148 kJ/mol (2.0× amplification factor). Calculated from NIST heat of formation: ΔHf = 168 ± 3 kJ/mol → BDE = (6×716.68 + 8×218.0) - 168 = 5876 kJ/mol. Tests core hypothesis: does CYCLE topology create amplification, or just electron count? CORRECTED from previous value (5845, +43 kJ/mol) which underestimated by 72% (-31 kJ/mol error).
energies.source: Fang & Rogers, J. Org. Chem. 1992, 57:2294-2297; NIST Chemistry WebBook
energies.method: Heat of formation from calorimetric hydrogenation
energies.confidence_note: NIST-verified experimental value. ΔHf = 168 ± 3 kJ/mol from Fang & Rogers 1992. Total BDE calculated from atomic formation energies (C: 716.68, H: 218.0 kJ/mol).

reference_energies.comment: Standard bond energies (kJ/mol) for naive calculation. Naive = 3(C=C) + 2(C-C) + 8(C-H) = 3(602) + 2(346) + 8(413) = 5802 kJ/mol

notes: 1,3,5-Hexatriene has same number of π-electrons as benzene (6)
Predicted violation: +30 to +50 kJ/mol (vs benzene's +148 kJ/mol)
Tests whether cycle topology or electron count drives amplification
Conjugation exists but correlation decays exponentially in linear chain
No feedback loop: correlation flows A→B→C→D→E→F and dissipates
This is THE critical test to distinguish 'conjugation' from 'cyclic feedback'
If violation is similar to benzene, cycle doesn't matter (hypothesis FALSE)
If violation is much lower than benzene, cycle IS the amplifier (hypothesis TRUE)
